newsitem.title: CHINA: China shares end mixed with Shenzhen B on holiday.
newsitem.headline: China shares end mixed with Shenzhen B on holiday.

text.p: China's stock markets ended mixed on Monday with trading in Shenzhen's hard currency B shares halted due to a holiday in Hong Kong, brokers said.
Shanghai's foreign currency B shares rose slightly on Monday after a late spurt of buying lifted the index out of negative territory, brokers said.
But the Hong Kong holiday limited both foreign and Hong Kong demand, which had helped push Shanghai B shares sharply higher on Thursday and Friday, they said.
The B index closed up 0.748 point or 0.85 percent to 88.424 points on turnover of $30.0 million compared with $65.159 million on Friday.

Domestic investors bought B shares in late afternoon trading after the index touched a low of 84.673 points, brokers said. Some foreign institutions also picked up quality B shares towards the closing bell, they said.
"There was a public holiday in Hong Kong so foreign buying was light," said a trader at a foreign bank in Shanghai. "After Hong Kong opens again on Tuesday it should be better."
All 47 of Shanghai's B share issues were traded on Monday with 22 gaining ground and 20 falling back. Five were unchanged.
Shanghai Shangling Electric Appliances Co was the top B share gainer on bargain-hunting after early losses, surging $0.024 or 9.45 percent to $0.278.
Heilongjiang Electric Power Co was the most actively traded B share on institutional buying, rising $0.090 or 9.02 percent to $1.088 on volume of around 4.6 million shares.
Shanghai's domestic currency A shares fell slightly on Monday due to weak sentiment, but the rise in the B index helped drag the A share market off the lows, brokers said.
The A index ended down 9.382 points or 0.79 percent to 1,179.442 points on turnover of 2.750 billion yuan against 3.287 billion on Friday.
The SSE30 blue chip index slid 23.722 points or 0.66 percent to 3,556.188 points.
Shenzhen's domestic currency A share index closed lower Monday on steady losses after a string of disappointing first-half company results, analysts said.
The A share index tumbled 9.73 points, or 2.59 percent, to 365.47 on turnover of 3.3 billion yuan compared with Friday's 3.4 billion.
"The results are darkening the market's mood each day and we still have a lot of uncertainties ahead," said an analyst at China South Securities said.
Many of the 22 A share companies that released their first-half operating results over the weekend showed lower profits.
Shenzhen Shenbao Industrial Co Ltd, Weifu Fuel Injection Co Ltd and Shenzhen Properties & Resources Development (Group) Ltd all reported a fall in first-half profits.
Shenbao's A shares tumbled their 10 percent limit, losing 0.83 yuan to 7.43 yuan to become one of the day's worst performers.
Shenzhen Properties also lost ground, shedding 0.38 yuan to 5.90 yuan. Weifu does not have A shares.
